args:
Is this article primarily about a new action or announcement by the Trump administration/White House/Executive? Respond simply with "yes" or "no" .
With one last stop, Bullis is too much and makes it three straight IAC titles
Adrien Stevens watched the frenzy unfold from his backside.
After tumbling to the court while fighting for a rebound on the final play of the Interstate Athletic Conference championship game, the Marquette-bound conference player of the year remained seated as Bullis students stormed from the bleachers to meet the Bulldogs at midcourt. When Stevens got to his feet, he avoided the scrum as he walked to the scorers’ table to join a developing handshake line.
When he arrived, he had just one question: “Where’s that trophy at?”
Saturday’s 55-53 win over Georgetown Prep in Potomac required every ounce of effort Stevens and his Bullis teammates could muster. They were pushed by the talented Little Hoyas (14-13) for the full 32 minutes, but the result granted the Bulldogs (20-7) a continuation of their recent dominance: For the third consecutive season, they claimed the IAC regular season and tournament titles.
“It’s really special to be a part of something like this,” said Stevens, a senior guard who led his team with 16 points. “Bullis has changed my life, so I’m just glad I could be a part of putting three banners up on the wall.”
After trailing 14-3 behind early sharpshooting from Georgetown Prep senior guard Patrick McDonough, the game’s top scorer with 17 points, Bullis had to regroup. The Bulldogs played a rigorous nonconference schedule, at times taking their lumps in the name of preparing for these moments. They contended with injuries and roster turnover, relying on new leaders to prosper and younger pieces to blossom. Each time, the Bulldogs answered the call. A 14-4 run to end the first quarter was Saturday’s answer.
“There are times when being a high school basketball coach is the best job in America, and knowing what these boys have been through, just staying together and trusting me, it’s just a great feeling,” Bullis’s Bruce Kelley said.
From the second quarter on, the game felt destined to come down to the final shot — and it did. Georgetown Prep had possession with eight seconds left, trailing by two. The ball worked its way to five feet beyond the top of the key. The final seconds were ticking off the clock, and the Hoyas’ attempt was on the way to the rim. Kelley could have sworn it was going in.
But the shot bounced off the iron, and the game was over. Queen’s “We Are the Champions” soon blared from the gym’s speakers. The Bulldogs wouldn’t dare tempt the basketball gods by practicing the ritual beforehand, meaning they finally could climb a stepladder to cut down the nets.
“That was the greatest feeling I’ve ever had,” freshman Xavier Skipworth said. “Coach always says we have to be a fist and not separate fingers. We knew they were going to punch hard, but we just had to stick together. We just did that.”
